===Self-immolation===
===Self-immolation===
On 17 January due to rising discontent with the country's state and the poor living conditions, and following the self-immolation of [[Mohamed Bouazizi]] in Tunisia, a man set himself ablaze in front of the Egyptian parliament;<ref>{{cite news|last=Zayed|first=Dina|title=Egyptians set themselves ablaze after Tunisia unrest|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/18/us-tunisia-egypt-immolation-idUSTRE70H3L720110118|accessdate=12 February 2011|newspaper=Reuters|date=16 January 2011}}</ref> about five more attempts of self-immolation followed suit.<ref name="TimeNoRev" />
On 17 January due to rising discontent with the country's state and the poor living conditions, and following the self-immolation of [[Mohamed Bouazizi]] in Tunisia, a man set himself ablaze in front of the Egyptian parliament;<ref>{{cite news|last=Zayed|first=Dina|title=Egyptians set themselves ablaze after Tunisia unrest|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/18/us-tunisia-egypt-immolation-idUSTRE70H3L720110118|accessdate=12 February 2011|newspaper=Reuters|date=16 January 2011}}</ref> about five more attempts of self-immolation followed suit.<ref name="TimeNoRev" />
â   â
===Online activism===
  â
[[We are all Khaled Said|We Are All Khaled Saeed]] is a [[Facebook]] group which formed in the aftermath of Saeed's beating and death. The group attracted hundreds of thousands of members worldwide and played a prominent role in spreading and bringing attention to the growing discontent. As the protests began, Google executive [[Wael Ghonim]] revealed that he was the person behind the account.<ref>{{cite news | title = Who is Wael Ghonim? | date = 8 February 2011 | publisher = [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] | url = http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2011/02/08/f-wael-ghonim.html | work = CBC News | accessdate = 17 February 2011}}</ref> Another potent viral online contribution was made by [[Asmaa Mahfouz]], a female activist who posted a video in which she challenged people to publicly protest.<ref>{{cite news | title = Women play vital role in Egypt's uprising | url = http://www.npr.org/2011/02/04/133497422/Women-Play-Vital-Role-In-Egypts-Uprising | date = February 4, 2011 | work = National Public Radio | format = transcript | accessdate = 6 February 2011}}</ref> Previously, Facebook had suspended the group because some of its administrators were using pseudonyms, a violation of the company's 'Terms of Service.' <ref>{{cite news | title = Can Egypt's Internet Movement Be Exported? | date = February 18, 2011 | publisher = [[The Nation]] | url = http://www.thenation.com/print/article/158717/can-egypts-internet-movement-be-exported | work = The Nation | accessdate = 23 February 2011}}</ref>
